Methodology: Spatial Capabilities and INLA

1 Bridging Theory and Method for Criminal Justice Analysis

1.1 Theoretical Framework: Spatial Capabilities Approach

The core conceptual model of this theoretical framework is the capabilities approach which provides a powerful lens for understanding how place-based factors influence criminal justice outcomes. Our theoretical framework integrates the capabilities process with spatial analysis to understand how geographic context shapes the translation of resources into actual opportunities.

flowchart TD
    subgraph SE["Spatial Environment"]
        direction TB
        PI["Physical Infrastructure"] -->|shapes| CF["Conversion Factors"]
        II["Institutional Infrastructure"] -->|enables| CF
        SI["Social Infrastructure"] -->|supports| CF
    end

    subgraph CP["Capability Process"]
        direction LR
        R["Resources"] -->|converted by| CF
        CF -->|enable| CAP["Capabilities"]
        CAP -->|achieve| F["Functionings"]
    end

    subgraph CO["Community Outcomes"]
        direction TB
        F -->|influences| CR["Crime Reduction"]
        F -->|supports| CI["Community Integration"]
        F -->|enables| SS["Supervision Success"]
    end

    style SE fill:#f0f8ff,stroke:#333,stroke-width:4px
    style CP fill:#fff0f3,stroke:#333,stroke-width:4px
    style CO fill:#f0fff4,stroke:#333,stroke-width:4px

1.1.1 Key Theoretical Components

Three Fundamental Elements

1. Conversion Factors: The mechanisms that translate resources into actual capabilities

  • Personal: Skills, health status, trauma history, decision-making capacity
  • Social: Community norms, social networks, cultural context, power relations
  • Environmental: Infrastructure, institutions, geographic location, environmental conditions

2. Capability Sets: The actual freedoms and opportunities available to individuals

  • Social Capabilities: Community integration, cultural connection, civic participation
  • Economic Capabilities: Employment access, skill development, financial stability
  • Health Capabilities: Treatment access, wellness management, healthcare navigation

3. Spatial Embedding: How capabilities develop and cluster geographically

  • Collective capabilities that emerge through community-level processes
  • Cross-boundary spillovers between neighboring communities
  • Place-based constraints and opportunities

1.2 Neighborhood Effects and Spatial Processes

The neighborhood effects framework illustrates how residential segregation by race/ethnicity and socioeconomic status creates differential access to capability-enhancing resources. This process operates through:

1.2.1 Physical Environment Pathways

  • Environmental exposures (air quality, pollution, hazards)
  • Food and recreational resources (access to healthy options, safe spaces)
  • Built environment quality (housing, infrastructure, transportation)
  • Aesthetic quality and natural spaces (parks, green space, community appearance)

1.2.2 Social Environment Pathways

  • Safety and violence (community safety, exposure to trauma)
  • Social connections and cohesion (collective efficacy, social capital)
  • Local institutions (schools, healthcare, community organizations)
  • Culture and norms (community values, expectations, social control)

1.2.3 Individual and Behavioral Mediators

The pathway from neighborhood conditions to outcomes operates through stress and behavioral mediators, highlighting how environmental conditions get “under the skin” to affect individual functioning and decision-making.

2 Methodological Integration: INLA and Capabilities

2.1 Why INLA for Capabilities Analysis?

The Integrated Nested Laplace Approximation (INLA) methodology aligns perfectly with spatial capabilities theory:

  • Theoretical Alignment
  • Model Specification
  • Policy Translation

2.1.1 Core Alignments

1. Multiple Conversion Factors

  • INLA handles multiple covariates simultaneously
  • Accounts for interaction effects between factors
  • Models spatial dependencies and hierarchical relationships
  • Captures the complex interplay of personal, social, and environmental factors

2. Spatial Embedding of Capabilities

  • Models neighborhood effects as collective capabilities
  • Accounts for spatial clustering of opportunities and constraints
  • Captures spillover impacts between communities
  • Reflects how capabilities develop collectively within geographic space

3. Uncertainty Recognition

  • Provides full posterior distributions rather than point estimates
  • Offers credible intervals essential for policy risk assessment
  • Quantifies uncertainty in capability measurements
  • Supports evidence-based decision making under uncertainty

2.1.2 Mathematical Framework

The INLA-BYM2 model operationalizes spatial capabilities theory:

\[y_i \sim \text{Poisson}(\mu_i)\]

\[\log(\mu_i) = \log(E_i) + \alpha + \sum_{j=1}^p \beta_j x_{ij} + u_i + v_i\]

2.1.3 Components Map to Capabilities Theory

  • \(y_i\): Observed correctional population count in census tract \(i\) (functioning outcome)
  • \(E_i\): Expected count controlling for population size (standardization)
  • \(X_{ij}\): Capability measures and conversion factors
  • \(u_i\): Structured spatial random effect (collective capabilities)
  • \(v_i\): Unstructured random effect (individual variation)
  • \(\beta_j\): Fixed effects measuring individual conversion factor impacts

2.1.4 Spatial Random Effects Decomposition

\[u_i = \frac{1}{\sqrt{\tau_u}}\left(\sqrt{\phi} \cdot z_i + \sqrt{1-\phi} \cdot \epsilon_i\right)\]

Where:

  • \(\phi\): Mixing parameter measuring importance of spatial clustering vs. individual factors
  • \(z_i\): Spatially structured component (collective capabilities)
  • \(\epsilon_i\): Unstructured component (individual variation)

2.1.5 From Spatial Analysis to Intervention Design

Collective Capabilities (\(u_i\)):

  • Identify capability clusters across geographic space
  • Map resource distribution and service accessibility
  • Locate gaps in community infrastructure
  • Target place-based interventions

Conversion Factors (\(\phi\)):

  • Assess how strongly place matters for outcomes
  • Evaluate barriers to capability development
  • Guide geographic targeting of resources
  • Plan coordination between neighboring areas

Individual Effects (\(\beta_j\)):

  • Measure direct impacts of specific conversion factors
  • Identify which capabilities matter most
  • Prioritize intervention components
  • Design individual-level support services

Recent advances in Bayesian spatial modeling (Rue, Martino, and Chopin 2009; Riebler et al. 2016; Simpson et al. 2017) have made complex spatial analysis more accessible.

References

Riebler, Andrea, Sigrunn H Sørbye, Daniel Simpson, and Håvard Rue. 2016. “An Intuitive Bayesian Spatial Model for Disease Mapping That Accounts for Scaling.” Statistical Methods in Medical Research 25 (4): 1145–65.
Rue, Håvard, Sara Martino, and Nicolas Chopin. 2009. “Approximate Bayesian Inference for Latent Gaussian Models by Using Integrated Nested Laplace Approximations.” Journal of the Royal Statistical Society: Series B (Statistical Methodology) 71 (2): 319–92.
Simpson, Daniel, Håvard Rue, Andrea Riebler, Thiago G Martins, and Sigrunn H Sørbye. 2017. “Penalising Model Component Complexity: A Principled, Practical Approach to Constructing Priors.” Statistical Science 32 (1): 1–28.
Source Code

title: "Methodology: Spatial Capabilities and INLA"

# Bridging Theory and Method for Criminal Justice Analysis

## Theoretical Framework: Spatial Capabilities Approach
The core conceptual model of this theoretical framework is the capabilities approach which provides a powerful lens for understanding how place-based factors influence criminal justice outcomes. Our theoretical framework integrates the capabilities process with spatial analysis to understand how geographic context shapes the translation of resources into actual opportunities.


```{mermaid}
flowchart TD
    subgraph SE["Spatial Environment"]
        direction TB
        PI["Physical Infrastructure"] -->|shapes| CF["Conversion Factors"]
        II["Institutional Infrastructure"] -->|enables| CF
        SI["Social Infrastructure"] -->|supports| CF
    end

    subgraph CP["Capability Process"]
        direction LR
        R["Resources"] -->|converted by| CF
        CF -->|enable| CAP["Capabilities"]
        CAP -->|achieve| F["Functionings"]
    end

    subgraph CO["Community Outcomes"]
        direction TB
        F -->|influences| CR["Crime Reduction"]
        F -->|supports| CI["Community Integration"]
        F -->|enables| SS["Supervision Success"]
    end

    style SE fill:#f0f8ff,stroke:#333,stroke-width:4px
    style CP fill:#fff0f3,stroke:#333,stroke-width:4px
    style CO fill:#f0fff4,stroke:#333,stroke-width:4px
```

### Key Theoretical Components

::: {.callout-note}
## Three Fundamental Elements

**1. Conversion Factors**: The mechanisms that translate resources into actual capabilities
  
  - **Personal**: Skills, health status, trauma history, decision-making capacity
  - **Social**: Community norms, social networks, cultural context, power relations  
  - **Environmental**: Infrastructure, institutions, geographic location, environmental conditions

**2. Capability Sets**: The actual freedoms and opportunities available to individuals

  - **Social Capabilities**: Community integration, cultural connection, civic participation
  - **Economic Capabilities**: Employment access, skill development, financial stability
  - **Health Capabilities**: Treatment access, wellness management, healthcare navigation

**3. Spatial Embedding**: How capabilities develop and cluster geographically
  
  - **Collective capabilities** that emerge through community-level processes
  - **Cross-boundary spillovers** between neighboring communities
  - **Place-based constraints** and opportunities
:::


## Neighborhood Effects and Spatial Processes

```{r neighborhood-effects, echo=FALSE, fig.cap="Figure 2: Neighborhood Effects Framework - How Place Shapes Capabilities", fig.align="center"}
#| out-width: "100%"
#| out-height: "auto"
knitr::include_graphics("figures/neighborhood_effects.png")
```

The neighborhood effects framework illustrates how **residential segregation by race/ethnicity and socioeconomic status** creates differential access to capability-enhancing resources. This process operates through:

### Physical Environment Pathways
- **Environmental exposures** (air quality, pollution, hazards)
- **Food and recreational resources** (access to healthy options, safe spaces)
- **Built environment quality** (housing, infrastructure, transportation)
- **Aesthetic quality and natural spaces** (parks, green space, community appearance)

### Social Environment Pathways  
- **Safety and violence** (community safety, exposure to trauma)
- **Social connections and cohesion** (collective efficacy, social capital)
- **Local institutions** (schools, healthcare, community organizations)
- **Culture and norms** (community values, expectations, social control)

### Individual and Behavioral Mediators
The pathway from neighborhood conditions to outcomes operates through **stress and behavioral mediators**, highlighting how environmental conditions get "under the skin" to affect individual functioning and decision-making.

---

# Methodological Integration: INLA and Capabilities

## Why INLA for Capabilities Analysis?

The Integrated Nested Laplace Approximation (INLA) methodology aligns perfectly with spatial capabilities theory:

::: {.panel-tabset}

## Theoretical Alignment

### Core Alignments

**1. Multiple Conversion Factors**

- INLA handles multiple covariates simultaneously
- Accounts for interaction effects between factors
- Models spatial dependencies and hierarchical relationships
- Captures the complex interplay of personal, social, and environmental factors

**2. Spatial Embedding of Capabilities**

- Models neighborhood effects as collective capabilities
- Accounts for spatial clustering of opportunities and constraints
- Captures spillover impacts between communities
- Reflects how capabilities develop collectively within geographic space

**3. Uncertainty Recognition**

- Provides full posterior distributions rather than point estimates
- Offers credible intervals essential for policy risk assessment
- Quantifies uncertainty in capability measurements
- Supports evidence-based decision making under uncertainty

## Model Specification

### Mathematical Framework

The INLA-BYM2 model operationalizes spatial capabilities theory:

$$y_i \sim \text{Poisson}(\mu_i)$$

$$\log(\mu_i) = \log(E_i) + \alpha + \sum_{j=1}^p \beta_j x_{ij} + u_i + v_i$$

### Components Map to Capabilities Theory

- **$y_i$**: Observed correctional population count in census tract $i$ (functioning outcome)
- **$E_i$**: Expected count controlling for population size (standardization)
- **$X_{ij}$**: Capability measures and conversion factors
- **$u_i$**: Structured spatial random effect (**collective capabilities**)
- **$v_i$**: Unstructured random effect (individual variation)
- **$\beta_j$**: Fixed effects measuring individual conversion factor impacts

### Spatial Random Effects Decomposition

$$u_i = \frac{1}{\sqrt{\tau_u}}\left(\sqrt{\phi} \cdot z_i + \sqrt{1-\phi} \cdot \epsilon_i\right)$$

Where:

- **$\phi$**: Mixing parameter measuring importance of spatial clustering vs. individual factors
- **$z_i$**: Spatially structured component (collective capabilities)
- **$\epsilon_i$**: Unstructured component (individual variation)

## Policy Translation

### From Spatial Analysis to Intervention Design

**Collective Capabilities ($u_i$)**:

- Identify capability clusters across geographic space
- Map resource distribution and service accessibility  
- Locate gaps in community infrastructure
- Target place-based interventions

**Conversion Factors ($\phi$)**:

- Assess how strongly place matters for outcomes
- Evaluate barriers to capability development
- Guide geographic targeting of resources
- Plan coordination between neighboring areas

**Individual Effects ($\beta_j$)**:

- Measure direct impacts of specific conversion factors
- Identify which capabilities matter most
- Prioritize intervention components
- Design individual-level support services

:::

#| out-width: "100%"

knitr::include_graphics("figures/Mermaid_Capabilities_Figure3.png")

Recent advances in Bayesian spatial modeling [@rue2009approximate; @riebler2016intuitive; @simpson2017penalising] have made complex spatial analysis more accessible.
